user.biography:
Megan {dietitian} & Judy {OT feeding therapist}
📱Online courses 
👶 Babies: Infant Self-Feeding
👧 Toddlers/kids: Prevent/manage picky eating

node.text:
Dr. Jazmine McCoy of @themompsychologist offers tangible tips for parents of young children who want to actively raise them to be anti-racist. Check out more resources at @themompsychologist and on her YouTube channel! Thank you Dr. Jazmine for your willingness to partner with us to offer extremely valuable education on this important topic ❤️❤️❤️
•
Don’t forget to tag a parent who is learning, growing and aiming to put in the work to change the future for all our children.
•
Our 100% fundraiser sale on our online courses ends tonight {Saturday} at 11:59 PM EST. All sales made since we launched this sale Thursday night will benefit @appetiteforchange. Please head back one slide for more info.
•
We will resume feeding content on Sunday. Later today in our stories we will share how we hope to continue to actively evolve as a company and as individuals in working toward anti-racism.

node.title: Raising Anti-Racist Children: Starting the Conversation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 22, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'FOODS I DON'T ENJOY: Beets Shrimp Olives FOODS I STILL SERVE το MY KIDS: Beets Shrimp Olives feedinglittles'.

node.text:
What foods do you suuuuuper dislike? Tell us ⬇️⬇️⬇️ We polled a few team members and beets, shrimp and olives came up as their least favorite foods.
 
Maybe your list of foods you won’t eat is pretty long. Maybe you struggle with picky eating as an adult, and you don’t want to pass on you dislikes to their kids. After all, if they know you won’t touch it, they’re less likely to eat it themselves.
•
Guess what? You can navigate this. Everyone has foods they like and dislike. We don’t HAVE to love every food on the planet. Here are some tips:
•
1) Serve the food you don’t like to your kids when you can. We easily write off foods we don’t enjoy, but when we don’t serve them our kids don’t learn to eat them either.
•
2) Model interacting with the food, even if you just pick it up and smell it. While you may not be ready to eat it {ever}, your child will see it on your plate and will know that you’re OK touching it. Side note: many of you have shared that our Toddler Course strategies have helped with your partner’s eating habits, or even your own! Sometimes these baby steps can help you learn to enjoy that food one day.
•
3) Keep language about the food neutral. You don’t have to lie to your kid and say you love it, but try to avoid saying you hate it. {Kids pick up on that so fast and won’t even touch the food.} Phrases like, “That’s not for me right now,” “I am really enjoying my strawberries,” or a simple “No thank you/not right now” are all great ways to politely decline food. Turning it back to your child can help too: “I’m eating my chicken right now, but I know how much you love those peas! Want to show me how many you can line up in a row?”
•
4) The goal is for our kids to eventually like most foods...but they won’t like every single thing on their plate. That’s OK! We want them to be able to identify the foods that they enjoy the most and that make them feel their best. As they get older they will realize that you don’t like or eat every food either. They may learn that they eat differently than their friends. Give them the opportunity to explore all types of food and try to keep mealtime positive, even if you’re not an adventurous eater yourself.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I'm glad I spent all this money on a high chair just for my kid to sit on my lap. feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Does your toddler LOVE sitting in your lap at mealtime? Yeah, it’s a thing. If you’re getting frustrated with it, here are some tips ⬇️⬇️⬇️

1️⃣ They may be craving connection with you, especially if you haven’t seen them all day. Remember that this phase is temporary {we promise!} and that they may just need physical touch and close proximity if they’re missing you. That’s ok! Cuddle your sweet babe and let them sit on your lap if it works for you. Try lots of cuddles and babywearing if their size permits before mealtime to ease the transition.
2️⃣ Perhaps their chair isn’t comfortable or conducive to supportive sitting. Click our link in bio to check out our Favorite High Chairs and Boosters post, where we talk about the importance of positioning at the table and how to make your child’s chair more supportive.
3️⃣ Sometimes sitting on your lap becomes habit - it could be time to shake up mealtime routines and start laying a new foundation. Try a carpet picnic or a change of scenery where your child has a chance to sit in their own spot. 
4️⃣ If you really need some personal space, sitting your child very close to you can help them feel secure and fulfill their need to be next to you. Slide their chair up close to yours so they know you’re nearby. It’s OK to say “I need my own space while we eat. Why don’t you sit right next to me and show me how you use your fork!”

Don’t forget that our Toddler Course is here to help you with frustrating mealtime behavior - check it out at feedinglittles.com ❤️❤️❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Feeding Littles on July 20, 2021 tagging @munchkininc, @numnuminc, @gerber, and @avanchyshop. May be an image of text that says 'feedinglittles "How can Ihelp my kid learn to use utensils?" Purchase forks and spoons that look and function like adult forks and spoons, just smaller. Once your child can use them, offer your "regular" family cutlery. Short handle Avanchy'.

node.text:
Let’s talk SILVERWARE {and how to help your kids use it eventually}! Tag a friend with a baby or toddler at home who could use some tips!
•
Judy here! 👋 I am an OT Feeding Therapist, and one thing I recommend with silverware is that it’s so important to ➡️keep it small and ➡️keep it simple. You do not need to invest in a bunch of different types of spoons and forks, and interestingly, the products we recommend for infants can be used well into toddlerhood – no need to have multiple types for multiple ages if you don’t want to. Just remember:
☑️Short, wide handle
☑️Looks and functions like a real fork or spoon
☑️Can hold onto food well
•
Our Amazon shop is full of our favorite utensils!
•
You can also use “real” spoons and forks with young children – just be careful with sharp tines on forks.
•
How can I help them use utensils?
1) Touching food with their hands and messy exploration at mealtime is still #1.
2) Starting at 6 months, also offer loaded utensils to your child. They need practice to learn, but every kiddo will do this differently. It’s not a race - it’s a process ❤️
3) We don’t expect most toddlers to independently use utensils {scooping with a spoon, stabbing food with a fork} until closer to 16-18 months if they have been practicing regularly. If they need more help, try the activities in the chart {swipe through} and work with your provider.
4) Never force your child to use utensils. It’s ok for them to default to their hands.
•
If you’re doing those things, you’re well on your way to successful utensil usage 🙌 Just remember, EVERY KIDDO IS DIFFERENT ❤️
•
What if my child always defaults to using their hands? ➡️➡️ The biggest issue is - CAN they use utensils? Are they using their hands for other tasks even if they put down the fork at mealtime? Are they using their hands in their daily play? If the answer is yes, we generally don’t worry about utensil use as long as your child is *able* to use them and shows progression toward more coordinated use of their hands as they get older.
•
Need more help feeding your baby or toddler? Head to feedinglittles.com to check out our online courses!

node.text:
WEIRD THINGS KIDS DO WITH UTENSILS 🍴🥄 {that are completely “normal” and expected}!
•
Friends, tomorrow we will share all our tips and techniques for helping your child learn to use forks and spoons…but today, let’s celebrate the funny things kids do as they are learning! Does your kid do any of these?
•
Toddlers want so badly to “DO MYSELF.” They watch you use your fork like a pro and try their hardest to do it too, even if they have a few hiccups along the way. It’s super common for them to:
➕Hold a spoon in one hand, eat with the other
➕Use the wrong end of the utensil
➕Pull food off their fork and eat it…instead of just putting the fork in their mouth 🙈
➕Not let you help them use utensils
➕Steal your fork {we recommend letting them use yours as long as it’s not too sharp!}
➕Default back to using their hands - it’s just easier sometimes!
•
What can you do? Let them continue to explore and practice 👊 Check back tomorrow for more tips by age that can help them become utensil pros!
•
Don’t forget that our online courses for babies and toddlers/kids are here to help! Get pro tips from feeding experts, right at home! Feedinglittles.com 👊

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'feedinglittles Myth: When doing Baby-led Weaning, don't offer any puréed or smooth textures. cauliflower purple carrot strawberry Truth: It's important for babies to learn to self-feed all safe textures. guacamole applesauce yogurt'.

node.text:
Even if you’re doing Baby-led Weaning {infant self-feeding}, it’s important for your baby to learn to eat all safe textures. Will you tag a friend feeding a baby who may find this helpful?
•
Baby-led Weaning, or Infant Self-Feeding, is an infant feeding technique where parents offer babies whole pieces of food to explore and eat from the start. Babies learn to lateralize food {move it to the side of their mouth} and chew it with their strong gums.
•
Many parents like BLW because it allows babies to eat what the family eats, practice chewing skills right away, and explore multiple safe textures and flavors. It can be a really fun, positive experience for many families.
•
We began teaching BLW when appropriate in 2013 and have seen the interest in this method increase dramatically in the last few years. Our online course has helped thousands of families navigate BLW in a fun, safe, flexible way without rigidity.
•
One thing we’ve noticed is that some BLW proponents believe that babies shouldn’t have puréed or smooth texture 🤔 However, so many foods we as adults eat are these textures! Just because you’re not necessarily spoon-feeding or using “baby food” doesn’t mean puréed textures are a no-go.
•
Hummus, guacamole, applesauce, sweet potato mash, yogurt, soups and sauces, mashed potatoes, and smoothies are tasty, nourishing foods that many adults eat regularly - it’s OK for baby to eat them too! Managing a wide variety of safe textures only helps your kiddo develop more oral-motor skills and be comfortable with different types of foods as they get older.
•
➡️ How do I offer a smooth or puréed texture to my baby when they’re doing BLW {feeding themselves}? Loaded spoons will be your friend! We love the @numnuminc GOOtensils {#neversponsored} because they’re the perfect size for baby’s hands and food sticks to them really well {note: the applesauce sticks to even the stage 2 spoon, meant for thicker foods}. Want a great, messy sensory experience? Let baby eat these foods with their hands! 😍😱

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 14, 2021. May be an image of food and text.

node.text:
Double tap if you love pancakes! 🙋‍♀️🙋‍♀️🙋‍♀️ This banana egg pancake recipe is a staple in our house that works well for eaters of all ages {babies included}! These freeze well and are a great way to use up extra bananas. Will you tag a friend feeding a baby, toddler or kid?
•
BTW, if you haven’t been seeing our posts…don’t forget to like and comment on this list to tell IG you want to see more @feedinglittles in your feed 😝
•
Megan here 👋 - we love this basic banana pancake recipe and hope your whole family will, too. My kids get really excited on pancake day and have loved them since they were babies.
•
You may see this recipe on the interwebs as just banana and egg, but we like adding rolled oats {or coconut flour/whole wheat flour, 1/2 cup} so it’s thicker and doesn’t fall apart as easily when cooked. You can use any kind of uncooked oats too. They’ll blend into the batter.
•
➡️➡️➡️ The recipe is super versatile and makes about 8 small pancakes, enough to feed 1-2 adults and 2 kids depending on how much you eat.
•
We love to double or triple the recipe, make a big batch, and keep the leftovers in the fridge (up to 3 days) for awesome fast breakfasts or snacks. They also freeze well! Just thaw and reheat in the toaster oven on convection or in the microwave before serving.
•
We added real maple syrup to the pumpkin variation because pumpkin can be a little bitter - you can omit it if you’d like! Use canned pumpkin purée.
•
What do you top these babies with? Depends on what you have right now ☺️
✔️Nut, seed or granola butter
✔️Smashed fruit or jam
✔️Butter, real maple syrup
✔️Dollop of Greek yogurt or whipped cream with cinnamon added
✔️Nothing! They’re great on their own too 🤤😋
•
Baby at home? Cut into slices they can easily pick up! Practice serving them cut into small pieces, strips, wedges or whole with toddlers and kids to practice different fine motor skills.
•
Egg allergy? 🙅‍♀️🍳We haven’t made these with an egg replacer, but @cookieandkate and @theworktop have some great eggless pancake recipes if you do a quick search!
•
Happy eating, friends ❤️

node.text:
Let’s talk POOP for kids 12+ months! 💩 {Isn’t it amazing how much you talk about bathroom habits once you become a parent? 😂} Don’t forget to save this post for future reference and tag any friends who may be dealing with this!
•
What strategies helped YOUR kiddo? Please share!👇
•
Megan here - I see many pediatric clients for constipation issues. Sometimes addressing constipation is a multi-faceted and requires many strategies, but we oftentimes start with nutritional changes first.
•
A constipated kiddo can make daily life challenging. According to @mayoclinic, constipation in children is defined by any of the following:
➕less than 3 bowel movements a week
➕stool that is hard, dry or difficult to pass
➕larger than normal stool
➕pain with a BM
➕abdominal pain
➕traces of liquid or clay-like stool or blood on the surface of hard stool
•
Some tips to try now: 
➕Increase water - offer it freely throughout the day at 12+ months.
➕Try “p” fruits like prunes, pears, peaches and plums - in whole fruit form or diluted juice.
➕See if bananas, rice, cheese, potatoes or applesauce might be contributing to constipation - sometimes they do, sometimes they don’t.
➕Sometimes cows milk can be constipating - try an alternative milk to rule out issues.
•
We have a ton of additional techniques in a Constipation Strategies handout, found in both of our online courses.
•
Potty training {and a resultant fear of using the toilet} and medications can also affect constipation. If your child exhibits any concerning symptoms, talk to your doc! These nutritional strategies do not replace medical advice.
•
Check out our link in bio for our Sweet Berry Constipation Smoothie Recipe!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 12, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'These foods provide nutrition... ...but so do these foods: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Let’s talk about our culture’s obsession with VEGGIES for a moment. Will you tag a friend who might appreciate this?
•
Please make sure to read the whole caption - we are NOT saying veggies aren’t important, friends. They’re just not the whole story.
•
Don’t forget that our summer sale ends TONIGHT (Monday)! Code: SUMMER2021 at feedinglittles.com ❤️
•
I {Megan} want to tell you what sparked this post. I saw a message from a follower we hadn’t communicated with before. She asked “Where are the veggies?” in response to my daughters’ lunch of PBJ, cheese, cucumbers, strawberries and dark chocolate 🤔
•
I’m sure it came from a good place, but it took me aback and made me think about the bigger picture.
•
Why yes, there actually was a vegetable…but even if there wasn’t, does it matter?
Why do we feel the need to call out other parents on what they feed their own kids?
What if I had just given them a plate o’ veggies for snack and we were skipping them for lunch?
What if I didn’t have any in the fridge?
What if my kid was working through some food selectivity and I needed one less battle for the day?
What if I just flat out didn’t want to serve veggies?
•
My kids’ lunch was nutritionally balanced, delicious, and fun. Why wasn’t it “good enough?” Adding 28382838 veggies doesn’t make it suddenly much better. 
•
We get so preoccupied with making sure our kids “eat their veggies” that we sometimes forget that other food contains nutrition too. Watermelon has more lycopene than raw tomatoes. Whole grain bread is a great source of fiber and B vitamins - and even protein. Chicken nuggets may be the main source of iron in your kids’ diet.
•
Nutrition is not black-and-white, and while yes…we love veggies and recommend serving them often, the other foods matter too. And food is food. One is not morally superior than the other - they’re just different.
•
I personally think this veggie obsession stems from diet culture, where veggies are elevated because they’re “free” or so low in calories that they don’t “count”…if they were higher in calories or carbs would our culture be so obsessed? 🤔 But that’s another post…
•
You’re doing awesome, friends. With veggies...or without ❤️

node.text:
UGHHHh does this ever happen in your house? 🙄🙄 Tag a friend who might be dealing with it too ⬇️⬇️
•
When one kid says they’re full, independent of how much everyone else has eaten, suddenly everyone wants to be done with their meal. Sometimes this is inevitable when all the cousins are together or your kids are at a birthday party, but if you’re noticing it become more frequent at home here are some tips:
•
1) What we’re trying to teach kids over time is to stay at the table until all of their dining partners are finished. THIS IS A PROCESS. Stay consistent with your expectations, especially as they get older. Sure, a 1 or 2-year old is not likely to sit long for a meal, but your 4-year-old can likely understand that we wait until everyone is finished to get up from the table. Make sure you’re staying seated at the table as well! Set that expectation and stay consistent with it. 
•
2) Save an easy game or conversation starter for the end of the meal, especially if one kid eats faster than the other(s). The trick? In this game, everyone is still sitting. Go around and share your “high” and “low” for the day, or play “Who Am I?” and act out different animals or movie characters. If your child is pre-verbal, you can have everyone dance in their chair until someone says stop or point out different colors on the table.
•
3) Give your kids a job - this gives them a little more ownership in the meal and might make them more interested in staying. Maybe they bring up everyone’s plate, cup or napkin to the sink {age-dependent}. Maybe they let the dog out from the other room once everyone is done.
•
Just know that sometimes that peer pressure to be done with meals is STRONG. It’s ok to remind everyone that this is what’s for dinner, and we’re all done when we leave the table.
•
